<p>It’s still too early to tell, but as real income grows and inflation falls, the intent to splurge could further increase. </p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment%20uncertainty%20lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Generational differences emerged in consumers’ intent to splurge." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment%20uncertainty%20lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Omnichannel behavior</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p><em>Omnichannel gained traction.</em> Across Europe, 64 percent of consumers said they made apparel purchases across a retailer’s channels, compared with 24 percent who said they completed their shopping in-store only and 12 percent who said they only shopped online. In some markets, such as France and Italy, consumers said they shopped in-store more frequently than they shopped exclusively online. That said, the majority of consumers in these countries are still shopping across all channels, underscoring the importance for brands and retailers to create strong omnichannel experiences. To be sure, the omnichannel experience is becoming more important across categories beyond apparel, including for consumer electronics, jewelry, skincare and beauty, and furniture. In grocery, omnichannel is less important to European consumers. </p>
<p>European consumers still shopped in-store more than American consumers, although younger European consumers have made an increasing number of purchases across channels.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment%20uncertainty%20lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Consumers shopped across channels." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment%20uncertainty%20lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Environmental, social, and governance factors</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p><em>Mindfulness mattered. </em>Across apparel, food, household supplies, and personal care, about half of European consumers ranked a variety of health and environmental factors as important to them when making a purchase. These factors include whether a product is recyclable, whether the materials are sustainably sourced, and whether a brand engages in fair-trade practices. The absence of artificial ingredients, particularly in food and personal-care products, was also an important consideration for consumers. Relatedly, consumers indicated an interest in corporate transparency and altruism. </p>
<p>In Europe—and specifically in France and Germany—Gen Z consumers showed the most interest in these factors. </p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment%20uncertainty%20lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex6-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Health and the environment were key factors in purchasing decisions." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment/an%20update%20on%20european%20consumer%20sentiment%20uncertainty%20lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex6-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<hr>
<p>This snapshot of the European consumer reflects the complicated world around them, one in which uncertainty lingers. The survey results indicate that value may become a more important purchase consideration, but certainly not the only one. European consumers are open to new experiences and to discovering brands across a variety of channels, creating valuable opportunities for consumer goods and retail businesses across the region. Check out our <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise">ConsumerWise</a> page, and contact us for more information and additional insights.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>ABOUT THE AUTHOR(S)</strong></p>
<p><strong><a href="/our-people/jessica-moulton">Jessica Moulton</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinsey’s London office, where <strong>Nadya Snezhkova</strong> is a consultant; <strong>Thomas Rüdiger Smith</strong> is a partner in the Copenhagen office; and <strong><a href="/our-people/anja-weissgerber">Anja Weissgerber</a></strong> is the leader of strategy and operations for McKinsey’s Consumer Packaged Goods and Retail Practices globally and is based in the Berlin office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank the ConsumerWise team, including Christina Adams, Kari Alldredge, Emmeline Hale, Andrea Leon, Andrew Pitakos, and Jonathon Rivait, for their contributions to this article.</p>
<hr>
<p>This article was edited by Alexandra Mondalek, an associate editor in the New York office.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-A30155C0B5BD4C65B987D74D4081BEF4-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Couple window shopping and pointing at clothes they are excited about." style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-July2023" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>July 14, 2023</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>High hopes despite high prices: An update on European consumer sentiment</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>To save</strong> or to splurge? That is the question confronting European consumers, who have the most optimistic economic outlook they have had in at least a year, in the face of continuing price increases. For some, the answer is “both.” The following five charts highlight findings from our latest <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise">ConsumerWise</a> research survey, conducted in May 2023 in five European countries: France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-edge-to-edge StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__TLkZC mck-c-module-wrapper"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Consumer confidence</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p><em>A sunnier outlook emerges in Europe.</em> German consumers report the highest increase in net confidence, at 13 percentage points (up from –34 in September 2022), as well as the highest level of optimism—31 percent of respondents say they expect their country’s economy to rebound within two to three months and grow just as strong or stronger than it was before the conflict in Ukraine began. Meanwhile, French consumers report being the least optimistic, with 29 percent believing that the current crisis will have a lasting impact on the economy, with the possibility of a lengthy recession. (Across the continent, approximately one in five consumers expect the economic situation in their country to worsen.)</p>
<p>As has been true for the past two years, younger consumers and higher-income consumers report the highest confidence in a rapid economic recovery.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><div class="flourish-chart flourish-embed" data-src="visualisation/14212591?956372"></div></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Money-saving strategies</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p><em>Consumers are coping with continuing price increases.</em> Eight out of ten European consumers say they are taking actions to alleviate the ongoing pressure on household income. One in three consumers say they track their expenses more carefully, while just under a third say they are reducing their savings rate and dipping into their savings to cover expenses. And it’s not just low-income consumers taking these actions—higher-income consumers are adjusting their spending habits, too.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><div class="flourish-chart flourish-embed" data-src="visualisation/14213150?956372"></div></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Consumer spending </div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p><em>European consumers say they’re spending less on all categories. </em>Shoppers are buying fewer items and purchasing lower-priced alternatives. Given persistent inflation, however, their total spending may remain the same, even when making fewer purchases. Older consumers are most likely to reduce their spend across categories.</p>
<p>Consumers are reducing their spending the most in nonessential categories such as fashion, home decor, and dining out, while largely maintaining their spending on groceries, baby supplies, personal care, and pet supplies.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><div class="flourish-chart flourish-embed" data-src="visualisation/14270077?956372"></div></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Trade-down actions</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p><em>“Fewer” and “smaller” characterize purchases.</em> Looking for ways to stretch their income further, European consumers are claiming to trade down across categories in a variety of ways. Increasingly, Europeans are purchasing fewer or smaller items to reduce their spending, particularly when it comes to buying fresh produce and meat and dairy products. Shopping around for the best deals and buying in bulk remain popular strategies, while one in ten consumers say they would also switch to lower-priced retailers and lower-priced brands in the pursuit of savings.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><div class="flourish-chart flourish-embed" data-src="visualisation/14213551?956372"></div></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Intent to splurge</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p><em>Saving leads to splurging.</em> Money-saving actions don’t present the full picture of the European consumer experience of late: there’s also an intent to splurge, which is highest in Germany (where economic optimism is highest) and lowest in the United Kingdom. Like their American counterparts, European Gen Zers indicate the highest interest in splurging.</p>
<p>Among the roughly one-third of European consumers who plan to splurge, they express the highest intent to splurge on experiences, such as travel and dining out, and on fashion—the same categories in which they say they’re looking to save money. This indicates a strong intent to “save up” to splurge, meaning consumers might be spending less on those things daily so they can treat themselves to spend more later on.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><div class="flourish-chart flourish-embed" data-src="visualisation/14214473?956372"></div></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<hr>
<p>The snapshot of the European consumer today reflects the tension between intending to spend and save under the pressure of higher prices, albeit with more nuance than one might find in a typical economics textbook. These sentiment data indicate that value may become a more important driver of purchases—but certainly not the only one. Check out our <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise">ConsumerWise</a> page and contact us for more information and additional insights.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>ABOUT THE AUTHOR(S)</strong></p>
<p><strong><a href="/our-people/jessica-moulton">Jessica Moulton</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinsey’s London office, where <strong>Nadya Snezhkova</strong> is a consultant; <strong>Thomas Rüdiger Smith</strong> is a partner in the Copenhagen office; and <strong><a href="/our-people/anja-weissgerber">Anja Weissgerber</a></strong> is the leader of strategy and operations for McKinsey’s Consumer Packaged Goods and Retail Practices globally and is based in the Berlin office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank the ConsumerWise team, including Christina Adams, Kari Alldredge, Emmeline Hale, Andrea Leon, Andrew Pitakos, and Jonathon Rivait, for their contributions to this article.</p>

Find out in our latest ConsumerWise research survey."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-09-09T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDuring the third quarter\u003c/strong\u003e of 2024, European consumers reported feeling slightly more optimistic about the economy. Stabilizing household finances and reduced inflation concerns drove this increase in optimism. Trading down remained a common behavior, but new data suggests this trend may be shifting. The following charts highlight findings from our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;research in five European countries: France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Story Sept2024]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the third quarter of 2024, consumer optimism in Europe grew slightly, attributable to improved feelings about the economic and geopolitical climate. The tourism sector rebounded strongly over the past several months, supporting economic growth and providing a cushion against broader economic uncertainties. However, consumers remain cautious heading into the fall. So long as inflation continues to gradually decline, consumers in Europe may experience a modest increase in purchasing power, which may then translate into stable spending.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo contact us for more information or to read additional insights, check out our \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;page.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eABOUT THE AUTHOR(S)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/jessica-moulton\"\u003eJessica Moulton\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s London office, where \u003cstrong\u003eGizem Ozcelik\u003c/strong\u003e is a capabilities and insights specialist and \u003cstrong\u003eNadya Snezhkova\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior expert.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article was edited by Alexandra Mondalek, an editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader June2024]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDuring the second quarter\u003c/strong\u003e of 2024, consumer optimism in Europe grew slightly from the previous quarter, although most consumers continued to report having mixed feelings about the economy. A greater share of younger consumers said they planned to selectively splurge compared with older consumers, and they reported an interest in treating themselves to dining out and travel. As we\u0026rsquo;ve seen for much of the past year, consumers across Europe also said they continued to trade down. Together, these data indicate that consumers may have finally adjusted to higher-than-usual inflation, which suggests their shopping behaviors may have stabilized for the time being. The following charts highlight findings from our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;research in five European countries: France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Story June2024]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the second quarter of 2024, slightly more consumers in Europe reported optimism in the economy, marking an improvement from the previous year. As the year progresses, lingering uncertainties about the geopolitical climate may influence consumer spending patterns. Although consumers demonstrate somewhat conflicting behaviors\u0026mdash;selectively splurging, while also trading down\u0026mdash;they are likely to continue prioritizing value in their purchases. To contact us for more information or to read additional insights, check out our \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;page.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eABOUT THE AUTHOR(S)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/jessica-moulton\"\u003eJessica Moulton\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s London office, where \u003cstrong\u003eGizem Ozcelik\u003c/strong\u003e and \u003cstrong\u003eNadya Snezhkova\u003c/strong\u003e are consultants; \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/anja-weissgerber\"\u003eAnja Weissgerber\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;is the leader of strategy and operations for McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Consumer Packaged Goods and Retail Practices globally and is based in the Berlin office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article was edited by Alexandra Mondalek, an editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader March2024]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn the first quarter of 2024,\u003c/strong\u003e consumers in Europe once again reported having mixed feelings about the economy, but their concerns didn\u0026rsquo;t stop them from spending on discretionary items. Travel and self-care were two categories that these consumers expressed interest in. Even so, cautious consumers continued to trade down. The following charts highlight findings from our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;research in five European countries: France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Story April2024]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the start of 2024, consumers in Europe reported economic sentiment and behavior similar to the feelings and behaviors they reported in 2023. As we move further into the year, lingering uncertainties about the global economy and geopolitical landscape may continue to affect consumer spending habits. Consumer goods and retail businesses will need to provide value to their customers to battle these potential headwinds. These sentiments translated into various behaviors\u0026mdash;such as trading down\u0026mdash;that were also evident earlier in the year. Meanwhile, environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors continued to influence consumer behavior in Europe. The following five charts highlight findings from our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;research in five European countries: France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Story Jan2024]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEuropean consumers closed out 2023 engaging in many of the same purchasing behaviors they had exhibited throughout the year. Those feelings manifested into a range of behaviors\u0026mdash;for example, price became a more important factor in purchase decisions. A greater emphasis on the omnichannel experience, as well as health and environmental considerations, also characterized European consumer behavior in the third quarter of 2023. The following six charts highlight findings from our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/how-we-help-clients/consumerwise\"\u003eConsumerWise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;research in five European countries: France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Story Dec2023]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis snapshot of the European consumer reflects the complicated world around them, one in which uncertainty lingers. The survey results indicate that value may become a more important purchase consideration, but certainly not the only one. European consumers are open to new experiences and to discovering brands across a variety of channels, creating valuable opportunities for consumer goods and retail businesses across the region. grew slightly, while the percentage of consumers who said they were pessimistic decreased slightly in the second quarter of 2024. These shifts mirror relatively positive economic data out of the eurozone that aligned with the timing of our survey. Consumers who reported feeling optimistic attributed their feelings to stabilizing inflation rates, while consumers who felt pessimistic about the economy blamed their woes on ongoing international conflicts and the challenges posed by climate change. Even with these minor fluctuations, most consumers in Europe reported having mixed feelings about the economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers in Germany and Italy reported feeling most optimistic compared with consumers surveyed in other European countries. Consumer spending expectations on essentials fluctuated slightly from the previous quarter (for example, their net intent to spend on fresh produce grew one percentage point from the beginning of the year). Gasoline represented the biggest reported anticipated change in spending expectations, which may be because of increased driving related to summer travel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere were greater differences in quarterly spending expectations across semidiscretionary and discretionary categories compared with essential items. More consumers in Europe said they expected to spend more on hotels and international flights compared with the first quarter of 2024\u0026mdash;no surprise, given the upcoming summer travel season. Consumers also said they expected to spend more on jewelry compared with last quarter, which may reflect their relative confidence in the economy.\u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer packaged goods/our insights/an update on european consumer sentiment/june 2024/svgz_euconsumerwiseq2_ex3.svgz","alt":"Consumers’ optimism was reflected in their intent to spend on discretionary goods and services, which grew from the previous quarter.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"DC63C65956714B2593D417A304E79A39","name":"Exhibit 4","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eAfter a drop at the beginning of the year, more consumers said they plan to splurge over the next three months (up three percentage points to 37 percent) compared with the previous quarter. However, most consumers in Europe (63 percent) maintain that they do not plan to splurge. Gen Zers reported a higher-than-average intent to splurge, followed by millennials. When they did express an interest in splurging, Gen Xers and baby boomers said that they intended to treat themselves by dining out and traveling. Gen Z consumers, meanwhile, reported an interest in splurging on apparel compared with other age groups.\u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer packaged goods/our insights/an update on european consumer sentiment/june 2024/svgz_euconsumerwiseq2_ex4.svgz","alt":"Gen Zers reported the highest intent to splurge of any generation.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"6211FD32487440278181A0FADFEEB02C","name":"Exhibit 5","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eDespite their relative optimism and willingness to selectively splurge, consumers in Europe also said they would continue to trade down. Most frequently, consumers said they would trade down by adjusting the quantity of items purchased, a \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/consumers-spending-more-to-buy-less\"\u003ebehavior we have also observed in the US market\u003c/a\u003e, or choosing to shop at lower-priced retailers. Even as they expressed the highest intent to splurge, Gen Zers and millennials, particularly in France and Spain, were also more likely to report trading down than older generations.\u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer packaged goods/our insights/an update on european consumer sentiment/june 2024/svgz_euconsumerwiseq2_ex5.svgz","alt":"A greater share of Gen Zers also reported trading down compared with other age groups.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}}]}},{"id":"6F0D782B9F594C04B7B31B4FBBCB7A59","mediaID":{"value":"Sept2024"},"collapseTopSpace":{"boolValue":false},"collapseBottomSpace":{"boolValue":false},"desktopTextColumnWidth":{"targetItem":null},"children":{"results":[{"id":"54FC169B107F442BB0EF56CDFFD86C01","name":"Flourish 1 for Story","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eIn the five European nations we surveyed, although more than half of survey respondents still expressed mixed feelings about the economy, more consumers were optimistic than pessimistic in the third quarter of 2024. This may be due to inflation stabilizing in much of Europe and consumers feeling slightly less concerned about international conflicts. The Olympic Games, EuroCup finals, and summer holiday season may have also contributed to the improved consumer sentiment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn Spain and the United Kingdom, consumer optimism grew more in the third quarter than it did in other countries (up 6 percentage points each to 36 percent and 30 percent, respectively). Somewhat surprisingly, consumers in France reported an increase in pessimism (up 5 percentage points to 28 percent), despite playing host to the Olympic Games. This is particularly salient given that pessimism in Italy, Germany, and the United Kingdom fell. The uptick in pessimism in France could be attributable to frustrations that consumers there are feeling after the snap elections, which took place in late July.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers across all age and income groups reported feeling more optimistic than they did in the second quarter, though optimism was highest among Gen Z. This is similar to what we observed in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/19200725"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"C841BCB9F70E4746B8E7722E15591EF6","name":"Flourish 2 for Story","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eMost consumers in Europe (82 percent) either increased or maintained their spending from the second quarter, although slightly fewer (77 percent) said they increased or maintained their income. Indeed, nearly a third of consumers stated they started tracking their expenses more carefully.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/19203172"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"80CEC203F31C46F3B723FE7615BEB0E2","name":"Flourish 3 for Story","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eEuropean consumers remained cautious about spending. Across most discretionary categories, consumers said they planned to reduce their spend over the next three months. This was particularly true for home improvement and gardening projects, international flights, and hotel and resort stays, which is in line with what we would expect to see heading into the autumn months.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/19200867"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"A77726082DB04C6CAD12C8E2218DD6D0","name":"Flourish 4 for Story","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThe share of consumers indicating a desire to splurge over the next three months is holding steady, at slightly more than one third. Although dining out, travel, and fashion remain top splurge categories, slightly more consumers indicated a desire to splurge on items for the home, groceries, and electronics in the third quarter. This makes sense, given that the survey was conducted at the end of the summer travel season.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore Gen Zers continued to indicate an interest in treating themselves compared with any other age group.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/19202643"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"4EECE03FCEA74976A19C615618061C6D","name":"Flourish 5 for Story","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThe share of consumers in Europe who reported trading down in the third quarter held steady from the second quarter (76 percent versus 74 percent) and is down 4 percentage points year on year. The United Kingdom was an exception, with more consumers reporting trading down in the third quarter compared with the second quarter. (This may be due to ongoing concerns over inflation and the high cost of living).\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/19203026"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}}]}},{"id":"31F9AE26662342EF998351DA6917EE2C","mediaID":{"value":"April2024"},"collapseTopSpace":{"boolValue":false},"collapseBottomSpace":{"boolValue":false},"desktopTextColumnWidth":{"targetItem":null},"children":{"results":[{"id":"B4896FF089444D28A798AC4660F028DD","name":"Exhibit 1","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eIn February, consumers in Europe reported feeling slightly more optimistic than they did in the previous quarter, although they expressed far less optimism about the economy compared with consumers in the United States (23 percent versus 38 percent, respectively).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePolitical instability in Europe could help explain the difference in reported optimism between the two regions. Still, the majority of consumers in Europe, as was the case in the United States, reported having mixed feelings about the economy. Consumers in Europe who reported feeling optimistic about the economy cited inflation stabilization and advancements in medicine as reasons for their optimism. An improved job market also contributed to positive sentiment. Middle-income consumers, Gen Xers, and baby boomers reported the highest increase in optimism among demographic groups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEuropean consumers said their spending levels were similar to those of the previous quarter, and roughly one-third said they continue to monitor their expenses carefully. A small but notable margin of consumers said their savings increased or stayed the same this year compared with last year, indicating that household finances improved slightly.\u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer packaged goods/our insights/an update on european consumer sentiment/april 2024/euconsumerupdate-ex1.svgz","alt":"Mixed feelings characterized consumers’ mood across Europe.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"BB6CD90E3C4A4E048F131F294FC9BCFC","name":"Exhibit 2","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":""},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eConsumers said they expected to increase spending on home improvement and gardening supplies, international flights, and hotels, as well as sports and outdoor equipment. Likewise, consumers may have said they expected to spend money on travel because they were planning for the year ahead.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHigh-income consumers reported an increase in their intent to spend, particularly on categories such as sports and outdoor equipment, as they prioritize wellness in the new year. To cope with the pressure on household income, nearly eight out of 10 European consumers reported that they traded down, consistent with what we saw in the third quarter of 2023. Traditional trade-down behaviors include switching to less expensive products, shopping at cheaper retailers, or postponing purchases. Consumers across all income levels said they engaged in this behavior, and a higher rate of younger consumers reported trading down compared with older consumers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers in Italy and Spain traded down the most often, according to their responses. Most consumers who said they traded down did so by reducing the amount or size of the product they bought. This trend was particularly evident in Italy. In Spain, consumers who traded down did so most frequently by switching to a different retailer that offered lower prices or discounts or by opting for lower-priced brands or private-label products. These factors were particularly important considerations when consumers purchased personal-care products. Consumers also ranked the absence of artificial ingredients as an important consideration when purchasing food and household supplies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCorporate transparency and authenticity were important to consumers\u0026rsquo; purchase decisions in most product categories. In Europe, particularly in Italy and the United Kingdom, Gen Zers were interested in these factors more than older consumers were.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEuropean consumers cared about minimizing packaging and creating a neutral carbon footprint more than consumers elsewhere in the world did. Germany experienced a slight decline in consumer confidence, while Spanish consumers expressed increasing confidence.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInflation remained the top concern for two-thirds of consumers. French, Spanish, and Italian consumers expected to reduce their spending the most. \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer packaged goods/our insights/an update on european consumer sentiment/an update on european consumer sentiment uncertainty lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex2-v2.svgz","alt":"European consumers expected to reduce spend on nonessential items.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"1373876B5D244471B352BA6D8D935F5C","name":"Exhibit 3","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Money-saving strategies"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eTrading down picked up.\u003c/em\u003e Nearly eight in ten European consumers said they would take action to alleviate the ongoing pressure on household income, particularly in categories with high price volatility such as gasoline, fresh produce, meat, and dairy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThose actions included trading down\u0026mdash;specifically, switching to cheaper products, shopping at lower-priced retailers, or delaying purchases. Gen Z and millennials said they traded down more than other age groups, although all income groups traded down  at nearly the same rate. \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer packaged goods/our insights/an update on european consumer sentiment/an update on european consumer sentiment uncertainty lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex3.svgz","alt":"Consumers changed their behavior to cope with price increases.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"4F195FA4F728468EAD38A804CB9C2604","name":"Exhibit 4","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Intent to splurge"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eConsumers saved with hopes to splurge.\u003c/em\u003e While some European consumers traded down, about 37 percent of consumers surveyed planned to splurge. Like their American counterparts, European Gen Zers indicated the highest interest in splurging. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen it came to treating themselves, travel, dining out, and fashion were the three categories in which European consumers expressed the most interest. These also happened to be the same categories in which they said they wanted to save money. This indicates a strong intent to \u0026ldquo;save up\u0026rdquo; to splurge, meaning consumers might be spending less on those things daily so they can treat themselves to spend more later on. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s still too early to tell, but as real income grows and inflation falls, the intent to splurge could further increase. \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer packaged goods/our insights/an update on european consumer sentiment/an update on european consumer sentiment uncertainty lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex4.svgz","alt":"Generational differences emerged in consumers’ intent to splurge.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"95F98C62469C436C8DAE2525E64E2CB8","name":"Exhibit 5","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Omnichannel behavior"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOmnichannel gained traction.\u003c/em\u003e Across Europe, 64 percent of consumers said they made apparel purchases across a retailer\u0026rsquo;s channels, compared with 24 percent who said they completed their shopping in-store only and 12 percent who said they only shopped online. In some markets, such as France and Italy, consumers said they shopped in-store more frequently than they shopped exclusively online. That said, the majority of consumers in these countries are still shopping across all channels, underscoring the importance for brands and retailers to create strong omnichannel experiences. To be sure, the omnichannel experience is becoming more important across categories beyond apparel, including for consumer electronics, jewelry, skincare and beauty, and furniture. In grocery, omnichannel is less important to European consumers. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEuropean consumers still shopped in-store more than American consumers, although younger European consumers have made an increasing number of purchases across channels.\u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer packaged goods/our insights/an update on european consumer sentiment/an update on european consumer sentiment uncertainty lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex5.svgz","alt":"Consumers shopped across channels.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"827838212F2D48FAAB4DF4351D1DD54C","name":"Exhibit 6","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Environmental, social, and governance factors"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMindfulness mattered. \u003c/em\u003eAcross apparel, food, household supplies, and personal care, about half of European consumers ranked a variety of health and environmental factors as important to them when making a purchase. These factors include whether a product is recyclable, whether the materials are sustainably sourced, and whether a brand engages in fair-trade practices. The absence of artificial ingredients, particularly in food and personal-care products, was also an important consideration for consumers. Relatedly, consumers indicated an interest in corporate transparency and altruism. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn Europe\u0026mdash;and specifically in France and Germany\u0026mdash;Gen Z consumers showed the most interest in these factors. \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer packaged goods/our insights/an update on european consumer sentiment/an update on european consumer sentiment uncertainty lingers/euroconsumerwiseupdate_ex6-v2.svgz","alt":"Health and the environment were key factors in purchasing decisions.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}}]}},{"id":"739676B03F1142FCB76B6AD85D65DEC0","mediaID":{"value":"July2023"},"collapseTopSpace":{"boolValue":false},"collapseBottomSpace":{"boolValue":false},"desktopTextColumnWidth":{"targetItem":null},"children":{"results":[{"id":"D975E940884341F58344741DD668CF8D","name":"Flourish 1","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Consumer confidence"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eA sunnier outlook emerges in Europe.\u003c/em\u003e German consumers report the highest increase in net confidence, at 13 percentage points (up from \u0026ndash;34 in September 2022), as well as the highest level of optimism\u0026mdash;31 percent of respondents say they expect their country\u0026rsquo;s economy to rebound within two to three months and grow just as strong or stronger than it was before the conflict in Ukraine began. Meanwhile, French consumers report being the least optimistic, with 29 percent believing that the current crisis will have a lasting impact on the economy, with the possibility of a lengthy recession. (Across the continent, approximately one in five consumers expect the economic situation in their country to worsen.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs has been true for the past two years, younger consumers and higher-income consumers report the highest confidence in a rapid economic recovery.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/14212591"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"54848300B6CD46B2990FC1FA79CA2AC2","name":"Flourish 2","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Money-saving strategies"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eConsumers are coping with continuing price increases.\u003c/em\u003e Eight out of ten European consumers say they are taking actions to alleviate the ongoing pressure on household income. One in three consumers say they track their expenses more carefully, while just under a third say they are reducing their savings rate and dipping into their savings to cover expenses. And it\u0026rsquo;s not just low-income consumers taking these actions\u0026mdash;higher-income consumers are adjusting their spending habits, too.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/14213150"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"563264FD00054F3BB055BA4C96F88797","name":"Flourish 3","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Consumer spending "},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEuropean consumers say they\u0026rsquo;re spending less on all categories. \u003c/em\u003eShoppers are buying fewer items and purchasing lower-priced alternatives. Given persistent inflation, however, their total spending may remain the same, even when making fewer purchases. Older consumers are most likely to reduce their spend across categories.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers are reducing their spending the most in nonessential categories such as fashion, home decor, and dining out, while largely maintaining their spending on groceries, baby supplies, personal care, and pet supplies.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/14270077"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"E9FE6878E0D745C29FED145E930929AB","name":"Flourish 4","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Trade-down actions"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;Fewer\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;smaller\u0026rdquo; characterize purchases.\u003c/em\u003e Looking for ways to stretch their income further, European consumers are claiming to trade down across categories in a variety of ways. Increasingly, Europeans are purchasing fewer or smaller items to reduce their spending, particularly when it comes to buying fresh produce and meat and dairy products. Shopping around for the best deals and buying in bulk remain popular strategies, while one in ten consumers say they would also switch to lower-priced retailers and lower-priced brands in the pursuit of savings.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/14213551"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"968390F57F3041C99088338E5AE55B72","name":"Flourish 5","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Intent to splurge"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSaving leads to splurging.\u003c/em\u003e Money-saving actions don\u0026rsquo;t present the full picture of the European consumer experience of late: there\u0026rsquo;s also an intent to splurge, which is highest in Germany (where economic optimism is highest) and lowest in the United Kingdom. Like their American counterparts, European Gen Zers indicate the highest interest in splurging.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmong the roughly one-third of European consumers who plan to splurge, they express the highest intent to splurge on experiences, such as travel and dining out, and on fashion\u0026mdash;the same categories in which they say they\u0026rsquo;re looking to save money. This indicates a strong intent to \u0026ldquo;save up\u0026rdquo; to splurge, meaning consumers might be spending less on those things daily so they can treat themselves to spend more later on.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/14214473"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}}]}}]},"interactive":{"results":[]},"sectionheader":{"results":[{"id":"FED7DC8E966B450A96EBB6FD40A46516","mediaID":{"value":"Jan2024"},"template":{"name":"Section Header"},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"An update on European consumer sentiment: Mixed feelings remain"}},"eyebrow":{"jsonValue":{"value":"January 26, 2024"}},"image":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer packaged goods/our insights/an update on european consumer sentiment/an update on european consumer sentiment mixed feelings remain/an update on european consumer sentiment-664648181-hero-1536x864.jpg","alt":"A middle-aged man with a pensive expression leaning on a half-full shopping cart while looking at products in the pasta aisle.
